metadata.title: Restraining Orders Complete Flow
metadata.source: San Mateo County Court Mermaid diagram (Restraining Orders-2025-12-23-013154.mmd)
metadata.description: Complete flow for all restraining order types: Domestic Violence (DVRO), Civil Harassment, Elder/Dependent Adult Abuse, Gun Violence (GVRO), Workplace Violence, and Triage.

Note.text: If you'd like specialized in-person help, San Mateo County offers in-person help for restraining orders Mondays from 8am to 12 noon and 1:30 to 3pm at the Self-Help office on the 6th floor

DV0.text: What do you need help with?

DV1.text: Ask for a new restraining order

DVCheck2.text: Are they someone you: dated, married, or had an intimate relationship with, or are related to (parent, child, sibling, grandparent — by birth or marriage?

DVCheck1.text: Do you want protection from someone who has abused you or your children? (Abuse can be physical, emotional, financial, or take place online)

DVTiming.text: Note: If you file for a Domestic Violence Restraining Order before noon, you should get a response from the court that same day.

DVStart.text: You may qualify for a Domestic Violence Restraining Order

DVMinor.text: If you're under 12, a trusted adult must help you file. Please contact the Self-Help Center in-person or online via LiveChat for assistance.

DVAlt.text: You may qualify for a different restraining order: Civil Harassment, Elder Abuse, Workplace Violence

DVNotQual.text: A restraining order is only available if there has been abuse. You may want to speak to a legal aid provider about other options.

DVForms.text: To start a Domestic Violence Restraining Order (DVRO), fill out required forms

DV100a.text: Step 1: Fill out DV-100 (Request for Domestic Violence Restraining Order)

DV2.text: Respond to a restraining order someone else filed

DV3.text: Change or end an existing restraining order

DV5.text: Renew a restraining order before it expires

DVCQ.text: Have a question about filling out the DV100? View common questions here:

DVQ2.text: Is it free to file a DVRO?

DVQ3.text: Can I ask for a DVRO if I already have a criminal protective order?

DVQ4.text: How fast can I get protection?

DVQ5.text: Can I get a DVRO if I'm under 18?

DVQA.text: What if I don't remember the exact dates?

DVQA2.text: What if I need more space?

DV100f.text: If you don't remember the exact date, estimate and explain (e.g., 'Around August 2020')

DV100d.text: If you need more space, attach MC-025 (Attachment Form) or use blank paper

Proof1.text: If you have proof (texts, emails, photos), attach it to your request

DV100b.text: In DV-100, item 5: Describe the MOST recent abuse first — give specific facts

DV100c.text: Use item 6 and 7 to describe earlier abuse, including the worst incidents

CLETSa.text: Step 2: Fill out CLETS-001 (Confidential CLETS Information). Only the court and law enforcement see this. The other party does NOT get a copy.

DV109a.text: Step 3: Fill out DV-109 (Notice of Court Hearing). You only complete items 1 and 2 — the court fills out the rest

DV110a.text: Step 4: Fill out DV-110 (Temporary Restraining Order Request). You only complete items 1, 2, and 3 — the court fills out the rest.

DVReview.text: Once forms are filled out, go to the Courthouse clerk to file them and ask for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO), or you may be able to e-file online at the court website

DVOptional.text: Do you also want to request other orders such as child custody or visitation, child support or spousal support?

DVPickup.text: Ask the clerk when your papers will be ready and how you'll be notified.

DVRead.text: When you get your forms back, read DV-109 (Notice of Court Hearing) and DV-110 (Temporary Restraining Order) carefully

DVCheckOrders.text: Was a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) granted? Check if the judge signed DV-110

DVTROYes.text: You now have a Temporary Restraining Order. It lasts until your court date. Keep a copy of DV-110 with you at all times. You can also take photos of it on your phone

DVTRONo.text: A TRO was not granted, but you still have a court date where you can provide more information to support granting a restraining order

DVServePrep.text: You must now serve the other person with your court papers. Someone 18 or older (not you or someone protected by the order) must personally deliver the documents before your court date - the sheriff or someone else may be able to do this for you

ServeWho.text: Would you like the Sheriff to servce your papers for you? You must have the address or location of the other person.

SERStart.text: Step 1: Fill out form SER-001 (Request for Sheriff to Serve Court Papers)

AltStart.text: Step 1: Choose your server. The server must be 18 or older and not involved in your case. You cannot serve the papers yourself

SER1.text: Item 4: Location of the person to be served. List home and/or work address and the times they are likely to be at each location. If you have more than one address, you can list both in item 4a and 4b and include the hours they will be at each place

SER2.text: Item 5a: Type of court papers. Write 'Domestic Violence Restraining Order'

SER3.text: Item 5c: Court hearing date. Use the date listed in DV-109, item 3

SER4.text: Item 5d: Deadline to serve. Check DV-109, item 6 for how many days before the court date service must happen. Subtract from the hearing date listed in item 3

SERSoon.text: Contact the sheriff's office as soon as possible via email, phone or in-person services. It may take them several days to attempt service

SERGather.text: Step 2: Gather your court papers to give to the sheriff

SERPacket.text: You will need: Completed SER-001, DV-100, DV-109, DV-110 if granted, blank DV-120 and DV-250, and any other forms listed on page 2 of DV-109 such as DV-105, DV-140, DV-108

SERDeliver.text: Step 3: Deliver your forms to the sheriff in person or via email or fax. Contact your local sheriff's office for instructions

SERConfirm.text: Step 4: Confirm with the sheriff that they received all forms and know your deadline for service

SheriffReturn.text: Did you recieve a Proof of Service form from the sheriffs?

SheriffServed.text: If the sheriff successfully served the other side, they will give you a completed Proof of Service form. This tells the court that the other person was officially served and allows the case to move forward

SheriffFailed.text: If the sheriff was not able to serve, they will give you a form showing when and how they tried. This is sometimes called a Declaration of Due Diligence

SheriffCheck.text: If you do not get any paperwork back, contact the sheriff's office right away to ask if they served the other side by your deadline. If not, you may need to reschedule your court date

SheriffFiling.text: Make sure the original Proof of Service or Declaration of Due Diligence is filed with the court. If it has a court stamp in the upper right corner, it has already been filed by the Sheriff's office

SheriffCopy.text: Bring a copy of the form to your court date. If you were granted a Temporary Restraining Order (DV-110), and the other side was served, and its a CLETs restraining order, police can enforce the order if it is violated

AltSafety.text: If you think it may be dangerous for someone you know to serve papers, ask the sheriff instead

AltDeadline.text: Step 2: Check your service deadline. Look at DV-109, item 6 for how many days before the court date service must happen. Count backwards from the hearing date in item 3

AltPapers.text: Step 3: Give your server all court papers to deliver. This includes DV-100, DV-109, DV-110 if granted, blank DV-120, blank DV-250, and any other forms listed on page 2 of DV-109 such as DV-105 or DV-140

AltDV200.text: Step 4: Partially complete form DV-200 (Proof of Personal Service). Fill out items 1 through 3. Your server will fill out the rest after serving

AltServe.text: Step 5: Ask your server to deliver the papers as soon as possible and before the deadline. They must complete DV-200 and return it to you

AltRefuse.text: If the other side refuses to take the papers, your server can still leave them nearby and note that on DV-200

AltReturn.text: Step 6: Once you get the completed DV-200 back, make a copy of it for yourself

AltFile.text: Step 7: File the original DV-200 with the court. Bring the stamped copy to your court date and keep a copy with you at all times

AltTRO.text: If you were granted a Temporary Restraining Order (DV-110), the restrained person can be arrested if they violate it after being served if it's a CLETS resetraining order

Attendhearing.text: Attend your hearing at the court on the day listed on item 3 on the DV109 you recieved. If you have evidence like pictures, text messages, or emails, you will need to print them out and make three copies of each piece of evidence. One copy is for you, one is for the judge, and one is for the other side. If you have witnesses who can help support your case, bring them with you to your court date.

DVA1.text: A DVRO can: Stop contact, harassment, or threats, require the person to stay away, make them move out, restrict firearm access, require support payments, create custody/visitation rules. It can also protect children, pets, and property. Police can enforce a CLETS restraining order.

DVA2.text: Yes. There is no court fee to ask for a DVRO. You also do not need a lawyer to file.

DVA3.text: Yes. A DVRO may still be helpful because: Criminal cases can be dismissed, and DVROs can include child custody, support, or family protection. You can have both at the same time.

DVA4.text: If you ask for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO), the judge usually decides within 1 business day after you file.

DVA5.text: Yes, if you’re 12 or older, you can file on your own. The court may ask for a trusted adult to help. If you're under 12, an adult must file for you.

DVA6.text:
Domestic violence is a pattern of behaviors used to gain or maintain power and control through:
- physical or sexual violence
- coercion and threats
- intimidation
- emotional abuse
- isolation
- minimizing, denying and blaming abuse on victim
        -  economic abuse

DVCustody.text: I want to ask for custody or visitation/parenting time orders

DVChildSupport.text: I want to ask for child support

DVSpousalSupport.text: I want to ask for spousal support

AbductionCheck.text: Do you believe that the other parent may take your child out of the nine Bay Area counties without your permission?

AbductionCheck2.text: You can ask the court to protect against this by completing form DV-108 and DV-145.

Abd3.text: File the following forms with your DV100: DV-105 (Request for Child Custody and Visitation Orders), and items 2 & 3 on the DV-140 (Child Custody and Visitation Order Attachment), DV-108 (Request for Orders to Prevent Child Abduction), and items 1 and 2 on DV-145 (Order to Prevent Child Abduction)

DVCustodyInfo.text: File the following forms with your DV100: DV-105 (Request for Child Custody and Visitation Orders), and items 2 & 3 on the DV-140 (Child Custody and Visitation Order Attachment)

DVCustodyHelp.text: How will the court decide custody and parenting time? The judge looks at what is best for the child — safety is the top priority. You can describe the current arrangement and request specific time-share.

DVChildSupportInfo.text: If you would like to ask for child support, check number 24 on form DV100. Then fill out and file FL-150 (Income and Expense Declaration) with proof of income (like paystubs) from the past two months.

DVChildSupportExplain.text: How is child support calculated? The court looks at both parents’ income and time spent with the child. Support usually goes to the parent who has the child most.

DVSpousalSupportForms.text: Check item 25 on DV-100, and complete FL-150 (Income & Expense Declaration) with proof of income (like paystubs) from the past two months. If you are also asking for child support, you only need to fill out the FL-150 once.

DVSpousalSupportExplain.text: How is spousal support calculated? The court looks at: The supported spouse’s financial need and the other’s ability to pay. Domestic violence can also be a factor.

RespStart.text: If you recieved any of the following forms: DV-109, DV-100, or DV-110, this means someone asked the court for a Domestic Violence Restraining Order against you

RespCheckForms.text: Step 1: Know what the forms mean. If a restraining order is granted, it could limit your contact with the person asking for a restraining order. If you and the other side have a child together, the restraining order can include orders for child support and custody. If you're married, it can include orders for spousal support, property control and/or restraint. A restraining order could impact your life in other ways, including preventing you from having guns and ammunition. You have a court date where a judge will decide if they will grant the restraining order, which can last up to 5 years.

RespCourtDate.text: Step 2: Review the forms. Check form DV-109, item 3. This tells you the date, time, and location of your court hearing. If you disagree with any part of the request, you must go to court

RespConsequence.text: If you do not attend your court date, the judge can grant a restraining order against you that could last up to 5 years

RespWhatAsked.text: Step 3: Read form DV-100 to see what the other side is asking for. Look at items 6 through 23

RespChildCustody.text: If you have children together, you may have also received forms DV-100 (which asks for custody or parenting time) or a DV-140 (which makes custody or parenting time orders).

RespTempOrder.text: Step 4: Read DV-110 carefully to see if the judge granted a Temporary Restraining Order

BranchTemp.text: Was a temporary restraining order granted?

FL150Check.text: Did the other side ask for child support, spousal support, or attorney's fees?

RespFollowOrders.text: If you recieved a Temporary Restraining Order, you must follow all temporary orders. If you violate them, you could be arrested or charged with a crime

GunHave.text: Do you currently own or possess firearms, firearm parts, ammunition, or body armor?

GunDecision.text: You must turn them in, sell them, or store them with law enforcement or a licensed dealer within 24 hours of being served with the restraining order

GunWarning.text: Do not try to purchase or possess any firearms, ammunition, or body armor while the restraining order is in effect

GunOptions.text: You can turn them in to the police, sell them to a licensed dealer, store them with law enforcement or a licensed gun dealer, or transfer ammunition to a licensed ammunition vendor

GunParts.text: You must also turn in any firearm receivers or frames, including parts that could be used or easily turned into a receiver or frame

GunFormPrep.text: After turning them in, fill out form DV-800 (Receipt for Firearms, Firearm Parts, and Ammunition)

GunFormFill.text: Fill out items 1, 2, 7, and your case number on DV-800. The police or licensed gun dealer will complete the rest

GunOtherForm.text: If the police or dealer uses a different form instead of DV-800, that is also acceptable

GunFile.text: You must file DV-800 or the alternative form with the court within 48 hours of being served. There is no filing fee

GunFileLocation.text: Take the original and a copy to the courthouse listed on your court papers. The clerk will file the original and return a stamped copy to you

GunEnd.text: Keep a copy of the court-stamped DV-800 or alternate form with you. If you violate this order, you can be arrested or charged with a crime

RespWantWrite.text: Would you like to respond in writing to the request before the court date? A written response lets the judge review your side ahead of time; not filing doesn’t waive your right to speak in court.

DV120Start.text: Step 6: Fill out DV-120 (Response to Request for Domestic Violence Restraining Order). Attach any evidence you already have (photos, texts). If you need more time for evidence, tell the judge at your court date.

DV120Caution.text: If you have a criminal case, probation, or were recently arrested, talk to your criminal defense attorney before filing.

DV120Evidence.text: When DV-120 is ready, decide if you also need to attach support or custody forms.

FL150Fill.text: Fill out FL-150 (Income & Expense Declaration) and attach pay stubs for the last 2 months. File FL-150 with your DV-120

DV125Check.text: Did the other side ask for child custody or visitation orders?

DV125Fill.text: Fill out DV-125 (Response to Request for Child Custody & Visitation Orders). File DV-125 with your DV-120.

DVFile.text: Step 7: File your forms with the court. There is no fee to file

DVServeResp.text: Step 8: Have someone else serve your Response papers

ServeChoose.text: Choose your server. They must be 18 or older and not part of your case. You cannot serve the papers yourself

ServeMail.text: Your server must mail a copy of DV-120 and any other forms you filed, like DV-125 or FL-150

ServeDV250.text: Your server must fill out form DV-250 (Proof of Service by Mail). You can help by filling in the top part of the form with the case number and court info

ServeDV250Sign.text: Your server fills out how, when, and where they mailed the papers, then signs and dates the form

ServeFile.text: Make a copy of the completed DV-250. File the original and copy with the court clerk

ServeStamp.text: The court will stamp your copy and return it to you. Keep it with your records and bring it to your court date

DVREntry.text: Do you want to change or end a restraining order that is still active?

DVROrderCheck.text: Make sure you have a copy of the current restraining order. This will be form DV-130 or, for closed juvenile cases, form JV-255

DV300Start.text: Step 1: Fill out DV-300 (Request to Change or End Restraining Order). Explain what you want to change or end, and why

DV310Start.text: Step 2: Fill out items 1 and 2 of DV-310 (Notice of Court Hearing and Temporary Order to Change or End Restraining Order). The court will fill out the rest

CustodyCheck.text: Are you also asking to change child custody or visitation orders?

DV305.text: Also fill out DV-305 (Request to Change Child Custody and Visitation Orders)

CopyStep.text: Step 3: Make at least 3 copies of each form. One for the other person, two for you, and the original for the court

FileStep.text: Step 4: File your forms with the court. There is no fee to file

DVServeCheck.text: Step 5: After filing, you must serve the other side with your request

DVServeMethod.text: Check DV-310, item 5c to see if the judge ordered service by mail or in person

DVServerChoose.text: Choose someone to serve the papers. They must be 18 or older and not involved in the case. You cannot serve them yourself

SheriffOption.text: Do you want the sheriff to serve your papers?

SheriffServe.text: Contact the sheriff in the county where the other party lives. Provide them with the forms to serve. They will complete a proof of service form for you

PersonalServe.text: Give your server copies of all court papers and a blank proof of service form

DVServerSafety.text: If you are concerned about safety, consider using the sheriff to serve instead

DVProofForm.text: Use the correct proof of service form: DV-200 for in-person service, DV-250 for service by mail

DVProofFill.text: Your server must complete the proof of service form. You can help by filling in the top portion with the case and court information

DVFileProof.text: File the completed proof of service form with the court clerk. Make a copy for your records. The court keeps the original and returns a stamped copy

DVHearingPrep.text: Keep your copy of the proof of service with your restraining order and bring it to your court hearing

DVPostHearing.text: After the hearing, the judge may issue form DV-330 (Order to Change or End Restraining Order)

DV330Check.text: Step 6: Does the DV-330 say that you must have a copy served on the other party?

DVEnd.text: You do not need to do anything further. If there is an order, be aware of when it expires.

DV330ServeStart.text: You must have someone serve the other party in person with a copy of the filed DV-330

DV330Server.text: Choose a server. They must be 18 or older and not involved in the case. You may want to ask the sheriff.

DV330Deliver.text: Give your server a copy of the filed DV-330. They must deliver it to the other party

DV330File.text: File the original and a copy of the proof of service form with the court clerk. Keep the copy for your records

DVRenewStart.text: Do you want to renew (extend) a restraining order before it expires?

DVRCheckDate.text: Check your current restraining order (DV-130 or DV-730) for the expiration date

DVRWhoFiled.text: Are you the protected person listed in item 1 of the order?

DVRIneligible.text: Only the protected person can ask to renew the restraining order

DVRWindowCheck.text: Is it 3 months or less before your order expires?

DVRTooSoon.text: You cannot apply yet. You must wait until you are within 3 months of the expiration date

DVRExpired.text: You cannot renew an expired order. You must file for a new restraining order

DVR700Start.text: Step 1: Fill out DV-700 (Request to Renew Restraining Order). Explain why you want the protection extended

DVRAttachOrder.text: Attach a copy of your current restraining order (DV-130) to your DV-700

DVR710Start.text: Step 2: Fill out DV-710 (Notice of Hearing to Renew Restraining Order). The court will assign a hearing date and fill out most of the form

DVRCLETS.text: Step 3: Fill out CLETS-001 (Confidential CLETS Information). Only law enforcement will see this

DVRFileHow.text: How would you like to file your forms?

DVRFileCourt.text: Take your original plus 2 copies to the court clerk. The judge will review your request. The clerk will tell you when to return for your court-stamped papers

DVRFileEfile.text: You can fill out and e-file through your court’s website. The court will return the documents electronically

DVRFileDrop.text: Place the original and 2 copies in a courthouse drop box. Include a rubber band or envelope. You must return to pick up your papers

DVRReviewForms.text: Step 4: Review your returned forms. Look at DV-710 for your court date

DVRServePrep.text: Step 5: You must now serve the other person with your renewal papers. Someone 18 or older (not you, or someone in the case) must hand-deliver them before the deadline. The sheriff or another adult can do this

DVRServeWho.text: Would you like the sheriff to serve your papers for you? (You must have the person’s address or usual location)

DVRSERStart.text: Step 1: Fill out SER-001 (Request for Sheriff to Serve Court Papers)

DVRSER1.text: SER-001, Item 4: List every address and the times the person is likely to be there

DVRSER2.text: SER-001, Item 5a: Type of papers — write 'Renew Domestic Violence Restraining Order'

DVRSER3.text: Item 5c: Court hearing date — use the date in DV-710, item 3

DVRSER4.text: Item 5d: Deadline to serve — see DV-710, item 4, then count backwards from the hearing date

DVRSERSoon.text: Contact the sheriff ASAP by phone, email, or in person — it can take days for them to attempt service

DVRSERGather.text: Step 2: Gather papers for the sheriff

DVRSERPacket.text: You will need: Completed SER-001, DV-700, DV-710, blank DV-720

DVRSERDeliver.text: Step 3: Deliver your packet to the sheriff (in person, by email, or fax — ask your county sheriff for instructions)

DVRSERConfirm.text: Step 4: Confirm the sheriff received everything and knows the deadline

DVRSheriffReturn.text: Did the sheriff give you Proof of Service?

DVRSheriffServed.text: Sheriff served the other side — you’ll get a completed Proof of Service form

DVRSheriffFailed.text: Sheriff couldn’t serve — they’ll give you a Declaration of Due Diligence

DVRSheriffCheck.text: If you get no paperwork back, call the sheriff right away. If service won’t be done in time, ask the court to move the hearing date

DVRSheriffFiling.text: File the original Proof of Service (or Due Diligence) with the court. If it’s already court-stamped, filing is done

DVRSheriffCopy.text: Bring a copy to your hearing. If the order is renewed and CLETS-registered, police can enforce it

DVRAltStart.text: Step 1: Choose your server (18+, not in the case). You can’t serve papers yourself

DVRAltSafety.text: If it may be dangerous for someone you know to serve, consider the sheriff instead

DVRAltDeadline.text: Step 2: Check your service deadline — see DV-710, item 4**, and count backwards

DVRAltPapers.text: Step 3: Give your server DV-700, DV-710, blank DV-720, and any local forms

DVRAltDV200.text: Step 4: Fill out DV-200 (Proof of Personal Service) items 1-3; your server fills the rest after delivery

DVRAltServe.text: Step 5: Ask your server to deliver the papers ASAP and before the deadline; they must complete DV-200 and return it to you

DVRAltRefuse.text: If the other side refuses the papers, the server may leave them nearby and note that on DV-200

DVRAltReturn.text: Step 6: Make a copy of the completed DV-200 for yourself

DVRAltFile.text: Step 7: File the original DV-200 with the court. Bring the stamped copy to your hearing and keep a copy with you

DVRProtectionDate.text: Your current restraining order is automatically extended until your court hearing

DVRJudgeDecision.text: At the court date, the judge will decide whether to renew the restraining order for 5 years or permanently

Starting.text: Start a Civil Harassment Restraining order

CRO.text: You may qualify for a Civil Harassment Restraining Order

CRONote.text: If you'd like specialized in-person help, San Mateo County offers in-person help for restraining orders Mondays from 8am to 12 noon and 1:30 to 3pm at the Self-Help office on the 6th floor

CROStart.text: What do you need help with?

Responding.text: Responding to a Civil Harassment Restraining order

Renew.text: Renew a Civil Harassment Restraining order

CHROIntro.text: A Civil Harassment Restraining Order is for someone who is not closely related to you or someone you haven't had an intimate relationship with. This could be a neighbor, landlord, or coworker.

CHROGrounds.text: It can be granted if the person has harassed, stalked, threatened, or harmed you emotionally or physically.

CHROMinorNote.text: If you are under 12, a trusted adult must file for you. Please visit the Self-Help Center in-person or online via LiveChat.

CHROWhatItDoes.text: A judge can make orders to protect you, your family, and your pets. Police can enforce it once granted.

CHROFormsStart.text: Step 1: Fill out the required court forms to ask for a restraining order

CHROGetForms.text: You can either print out the required forms, or you can get them from the clerk's office at the courthouse - Room A, Floor 1, Civil Division

CHROFormList.text: You will need to complete these five forms: CH-100, CLETS-001, CH-109, CH-110, and CM-010

CH100.text: CH-100: Request for Civil Harassment Restraining Orders. Explain what happened, what orders you want, and if you need protection right away (item 11)

CH100FeeWaiver.text: If there was violence, stalking, or threats of violence, check item 13a to ask the court to waive the filing fee

CLETS.text: Fill out CLETS-001: Confidential CLETS Information. This helps law enforcement. The other person will not see this form

CH109.text: Fill out CH-109: Notice of Court Hearing. You complete items 1 and 2. The rest will be filled out by the court

CH110.text: If you'd like immediate protection, complete the the CH-110: Temporary Restraining Order. Only complete this form if you are asking for protection right away. Fill out items 1, 2, and 3

CM010.text: Fill out the CM-010: Civil Case Cover Sheet. This tells the court the type of case you are filing

CHROOptionalForms.text: You may also want to complete optional forms, such as a fee waiver or a request to keep a child's information private

CHROCalendar.text: After completing and signing your forms, you must be attend a brief hearing with a judge where the judge will set a hearing date, and where your temporary order request will be heard. Go to the Presiding Judge's Civil ExParte Calendar at 2pm. You must arrive exactly at 2 pm in order to have your case heard.

CHROHearing.text: Step 2: File your paperwork with the court clerk in Room A, First floor, Civil Harassment.

CHROHow.text: File your paperwork by taking your original and two copies of your packet to the court clerk on the 1st floor, Room A, Civil Division.

CHROFee.text: If you are not alleging violence, stalking, or threats of violence, and you did not request a fee waiver, you must pay a filing fee of $435

CHROFeeDenied.text: If you asked for a fee waiver and it was denied, talk to the clerk or Self-Help Center about what to do next

CHROReviewStart.text: Step 3: Attend your hearing date given by the Judge where they will make a determination on  your long term Civil Harassment Restraining Order

RenewIntro.text: Do you still need protection once your current order (CH-130) ends? You can ask the judge to renew it for up to 5 more years

RenewWindow.text: Is it 3 months or less before the order’s expiration date listed on CH-130, item 4?

RenewTooSoon.text: You must wait until you’re within 3 months of the expiration date to apply

RenewFormsStart.text:
Step 1: Fill out court forms to ask for renewal
- CH-700 (Request to Renew Restraining Order)
- Attach a copy of your current CH-130
      - CH-710 (Notice of Hearing to Renew Restraining Order). The court will write the new hearing date in item 3.

CopiesRenew.text: Make at least 2 copies of everything (one for you, one for the restrained person)

FileRenew.text: Take the original + copies to the court clerk. They’ll file the papers and set your hearing date. Your order is extended until that date

ServeRenewPrep.text: Step 2: Serve the other side with your renewal request

SheriffAskRenew.text: Would you like the sheriff to serve the papers for you? You must provide an address or location, and there may be a fee for service.

SERRenewStart.text: Fill out SER-001 (Request for Sheriff to Serve Court Papers)

AltRenewStart.text: Choose another adult (18+, not in the case) or a professional process server

SERRenewGather.text: Gather CH-700 including a copy of your current order (Ch-130), CH-710, blank CH-720, and SER-001 for the sheriff

SERServe.text: Give the papers to the sheriff in person or electronically. Contact the sheriff's office for more details.

AltRenewGather.text: Give your server CH-700 including a copy of your current order (Ch-130), CH-710, blank CH-720, and any other required papers

ServeDeadlineRenew.text: Check CH-710 #4 to calculate the service deadline based on the number of days the judge listed in CH-710 #3 (count back the listed days from the hearing date)

ProofRenew.text: Get Proof of Service (or Declaration of Due Diligence) from your server and make sure it’s filed with the court before your hearing

PrepRenew.text: Step 3: Prepare for court — bring copies of all papers, any evidence of violations, and notes of what you plan to say

CourtRenew.text: Step 4: Go to court on the date in CH-710

JudgeDecisionRenew.text: The judge decides whether to renew the order

CH730.text: Fill out (or review if the clerk prepared it for you) CH-730 (Order Renewing Civil Harassment Restraining Order). Give your CH-730 and attached restraining order to the clerk so the judge can sign it. Ask for two copies of the filed order.

ServeNewOrder.text: Step 5: Serve the renewed order on the restrained person (you cannot servce it yourself) and file the signed Proof of Service with the court

RenewEndNo.text: The order is not renewed and will expire on its original date

RenewEndYes.text: Your restraining order is renewed. Keep a copy with you at all times

RC0.text: If you received CH-109, CH-100, or CH-110, someone asked the court for a Civil Harassment Restraining Order against you

RCDate.text: Step 1: Check CH-109 (Notice of Court Hearing) for your court date, time, and location

RCReadReq.text: Step 2: Read CH-100 to see which orders the other side wants (items 8-16)

RCTRO.text: Step 3: Did the judge sign CH-110 (Temporary Restraining Order)?

RCTROYes.text: Follow every order in CH-110 right away. Violating it can lead to arrest

CHGunHave.text: Do you currently own or possess firearms, firearm parts, ammunition, or body armor?

CHGunDecision.text: You must turn them in, sell them, or store them with law enforcement or a licensed dealer within 24 hours of being served with the restraining order

CHGunWarning.text: Do not try to purchase or possess any firearms, ammunition, or body armor while the restraining order is in effect

CHGunOptions.text: You can turn them in to the police, sell them to a licensed dealer, store them with law enforcement or a licensed gun dealer, or transfer ammunition to a licensed ammunition vendor

CHGunParts.text: You must also turn in any firearm receivers or frames, including parts that could be used or easily turned into a receiver or frame

CHGunFormPrep.text: After turning them in, fill out form CH-800 (Receipt for Firearms, Firearm Parts, and Ammunition)

CHGunFormFill.text: Fill out items 1, 2, 7, and your case number on CH-800. The police or licensed gun dealer will complete the rest

CHGunOtherForm.text: If the police or dealer uses a different form instead of CH-800, that is also acceptable

CHGunFile.text: You must file the CH-800 or the alternative form with the court within 48 hours of being served. There is no filing fee.

CHGunFileLocation.text: Take the original and a copy to the courthouse listed on your court papers. The clerk will file the original and return a stamped copy to you

CHGunEnd.text: Keep a copy of the court-stamped CH-800 or alternate form with you. If you violate this order, you can be arrested or charged with a crime

RCRespondOpt.text: Would you like to respond in writing before court? This is optional.

CH120Start.text: Step 4: Fill out CH-120 (Response). Attach any evidence (photos, texts, emails)

CopyResp.text: Make 2 copies of your signed CH-120

FeeWaiverQ.text: Do you need a fee waiver? (No fee if CH-100 item 13a is checked)

FeeWaiverForms.text: Fill out and file FW-001 (Request to Waive Court Fees) and items 1-2 of FW-003 (Order). You may qualify if you: get public benefits, have household income below the FW-001 guideline, or can’t meet basic needs and pay the fee

FileResp.text: File the original + copies at the courthouse on CH-109. No money is due if item 13a was checked **or** your waiver is granted. Otherwise, you need to pay the $435 filing fee.

ServePrep.text: Step 5: Have someone 18+ (not you) mail a copy of CH-120 to the other side

CH250Form.text: Your server must complete CH-250 (Proof of Service by Mail) and sign and date the form.

FileProof.text: File the original CH-250 with the court and keep a stamped copy

PrepCourt.text: Step 6: Prepare for court — bring 3 copies of each piece of evidence, any witnesses, and notes of what you’ll tell the judge

CourtDate.text: Step 7: Go to court on the date in CH-109. The judge will decide whether to grant the restraining order

GVRO_What.text: A GVRO is used to temporarily prevent someone from owning, buying, or possessing firearms, ammunition, or body armor if they may be dangerous to themself or others.

GVRO_Start.text: Start a Gun Violence Restraining Order (GVRO)

GVRO_Who.text:
Only certain people can ask for a GVRO, including:
• Law enforcement officer or agency
• Immediate family member (spouse, parent, child, grandparent) or someone who lives with them now or lived with them in the last 6 months
• The person’s employer
• The person’s co-worker (regular contact for at least a year + employer permission)
    • An employee/teacher at a school the person attended in the last 6 months (with administrator/supervisor permission)

GVRO_Limit.text: Important: A GVRO does NOT include stay-away or no-contact orders. If you need orders like stay-away/no contact, you may need a different type of restraining order in addition to (or instead of) a GVRO.

GVRO_FormsStart.text: Step 1: Fill out the required court forms

GVRO_FormList.text:
Required forms (typical packet):
• GV-100 — Request for Gun Violence Restraining Order
• CLETS-001 — Confidential CLETS Information
• GV-109 — Notice of Court Hearing
    • GV-110 — Temporary Gun Violence Restraining Order (ONLY if asking for immediate protection)

GVRO_SMCReview.text: Step 2: San Mateo — go to the Civil Department for judicial review (judge review happens BEFORE filing)

GVRO_SMCReviewTime.text:
San Mateo Civil Department timing:
• Judicial review is during Civil Ex Parte hours: Monday–Friday at 2:00pm
• You must be in the courtroom by 2:00pm (no later than 2:15pm)
• If you arrive after 2:15pm, the courtroom will not allow you to enter
• Check in with the Civil Department Clerk’s Office to confirm which courtroom Ex Parte will be in that day
• Your packet must be fully completed BEFORE 2:00pm
    • The clerk does NOT file the papers first — the judge reviews them, then they must be filed

GVRO_JudgeDecision.text:
The judge may:
• Grant a temporary GVRO and set a hearing date, or
    • Deny the request

GVRO_FileAfter.text: Step 3: File after the judge reviews/signs (as directed by the clerk/judge)

GVRO_ServiceRules.text:
Service rules:
• Someone over 18 (not you) must serve the papers
• The San Mateo County Sheriff will attempt service of process for restraining orders free of charge
    • Sheriff’s Office: 300 Bradford Street, 1st Floor, Redwood City, CA

GVRO_Hearing.text: Step 5: Go to court on the hearing date listed on GV-109

GVRO_LongTerm.text: At the hearing, the judge decides whether to issue a GVRO that can last up to 5 years.

GVRO_Read.text: If someone has filed court papers to ask for a restraining order against you, carefully read over the papers you were given.

GVRO_Respond.text: Respond to a Gun Vioelnce Restraining Order

GVRO_EPOQ.text: Were you served with form EPO-002 (Emergency Protective Order)?

GVRO_EPOExplain.text:
EPO-002 means a judge granted an emergency restraining order against you.
    You will have a court date listed on EPO-002, or it will be sent to the address listed under your name on the form.

GVRO_GV109Q.text: Were you served with form GV-109 (Notice of Court Hearing)?

GVRO_GV109Explain.text:
GV-109 means you have a court date.
If you do not agree to the restraining order, make sure you go to court.
    At the court date, a judge will decide whether to grant a GVRO against you that can last up to 5 years.

GVRO_GV110Q.text: Were you served with form GV-110 (Temporary Gun Violence Restraining Order)?

GVRO_GV110Explain.text:
GV-110 means the judge granted a temporary restraining order against you.
    You must follow all the orders granted by the judge.

GVRO_Warning.text: If you don’t follow the judge’s orders, you could be arrested and charged with a crime.

GVRO_ResponseOpt.text: Optional: If you want the judge to consider your side, you may file a written response before the hearing.

GVRO_ResponseForms.text:
Optional response form:
    • GV-120 — Response to Request for Gun Violence Restraining Order

GVRO_CourtDate.text: Go to court on the date listed in your papers. Bring copies of your response and any evidence you want the judge to see.

EA0.text: Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order

EA1.text: A judge can grant this restraining order to protect someone who is elderly (65 or older) or a dependent adult (18–64 with a disability) from abuse, neglect, abandonment, or harassment. Once granted, police can enforce the order.

EA2.text:
This restraining order can include:
• No contact
• Stay a certain distance away
• Move out (if the person lives with the protected person)
• Counseling or anger management
• Cannot own or have firearms, ammunition, or body armor
    • Other protections ordered by the judge

EA3.text: Who can ask for this restraining order?

EA4.text:
• The elder or dependent adult (for themself)
• The elder/dependent adult’s conservator or trustee
• Their attorney or guardian ad litem
    • A representative of Adult Protective Services (APS)

EA5.text: Where to file in San Mateo County

EA6.text:
These cases are handled by the Probate Department.
    If the person needing protection is 65 or older, the case is filed in Probate.

EA_Start.text: Start an Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order

EA_Step1.text: Step 1: Fill out the required court forms

EA_Forms.text:
Required forms:
• EA-100 — Request for Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Orders
• CLETS-001 — Confidential CLETS Information
• EA-109 — Notice of Court Hearing
    • EA-110 — Temporary Restraining Order (ONLY if asking for immediate protection)

EA_NoFee.text: There is no court filing fee to request an Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order.

EA_Copies.text:
Make at least 2 copies of everything:
• One for you
• One for the restrained person
    The original is for the court.

EA_Step3.text: Step 3: Take your paperwork to the Probate Clerk’s Office

EA_JudgeReview.text:
The clerk will send your paperwork to a judge for review.
If the judge grants temporary orders, the judge will:
• Sign EA-110 (if requested)
    • Set a hearing date on EA-109

EA_Service.text:
Service rules:
• Someone over 18 (not you) must serve the papers
• The San Mateo County Sheriff will attempt service of process for restraining orders free of charge
    • Sheriff’s Office: 300 Bradford Street, 1st Floor, Redwood City, CA

EA_Step5.text: Step 5: Go to court on the hearing date listed on EA-109

EA_AfterHearing.text:
If the judge grants the restraining order after the hearing, the long-term order is issued on:
    • EA-130 — Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order After Hearing

EA_Read.text: If someone filed court papers asking for an Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse restraining order against you, carefully read all the papers you were served.

EA_Respond.text: Respond to an Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order (If You Were Served)

EA_Check109.text: Check EA-109 (Notice of Court Hearing). This form lists your court date, time, and location.

EA_CourtNeeded.text:
If you do not agree with the restraining order, you must go to court.
    At the hearing, the judge decides whether to issue an order that can last up to 5 years.

EA_Check110.text: Did the judge sign EA-110 (Temporary Restraining Order)?

EA_ObeyTRO.text:
You must follow every order in EA-110 immediately.
    If you do not, you could be arrested and charged with a crime.

EA_ResponseOpt.text: Would you like to respond in writing before court? This is optional.

EA120.text:
Fill out EA-120 — Response to Request for Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order.
    Attach any evidence you want the judge to review (texts, emails, photos).

EA_PrepCourt.text:
Prepare for court:
Bring copies of all papers, your evidence, and notes of what you want to say.
    Arrive early.

EA_ServeResp.text:
Have someone 18+ (not you) serve your response as required.
    File proof of service with the court before the hearing.

EA_GoCourt.text: Go to court on the date listed in EA-109.

EA_RenewCheck.text: Do you already have EA-130 and it is going to expire?

EA_Renew.text: Renew an Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order

EA_RenewWindow.text: You can ask to renew the restraining order up to 3 months before the expiration date listed on EA-130 (page 1, item 4).

EA_RenewForms.text:
Required renewal forms:
• EA-700 — Request to Renew Restraining Order
• EA-710 — Notice of Hearing to Renew Restraining Order
    Attach a copy of your current EA-130 to EA-700.

EA_RenewCopies.text: Make at least 2 copies (one for you, one for the restrained person).

EA_RenewFile.text:
Step 2: Take your paperwork to the Probate Clerk.
The clerk will file the papers and set a hearing date on EA-710.
    Your current restraining order is extended until that hearing date.

EA_RenewServe.text:
Step 3: Serve the restrained person with the renewal papers.
Sheriff service is free in San Mateo County:
    300 Bradford Street, 1st Floor, Redwood City, CA

EA_RenewCourt.text:
Step 4: Go to court on the date listed in EA-710.
    The judge decides whether to renew the restraining order.

WV1.text: An employer can ask for a restraining order to protect one or more employees from someone who has stalked, harassed, threatened violence, or been violent at the workplace.

WV2.text:
Abuse at the workplace can include:
• Threats made in person, by phone, mail, email, or online
• Following an employee to or from work
• Harassment or threats during work hours
    • Violence or credible threats of violence

WV3.text: Who can ask for this restraining order?

WV4.text:
Only an employer can ask for a Workplace Violence Restraining Order.
    Employees cannot file this type of restraining order themselves.

WV5.text:
An employer may ask for protection for:
• One or more employees
• Other employees who may be at risk
    • In some cases, family or household members of employees

WV6.text: Where to file in San Mateo County

WV7.text:
These cases are handled by the Civil Department.
    Workplace Violence Restraining Orders must be requested during Civil Ex Parte hours.

WV_Start.text: Start a Workplace Violence Restraining Order

WV_Step1.text: Step 1: Fill out the required court forms

WV_Forms.text:
Required forms (San Mateo County):
• NOTICE TO PROTECTED PARTY SHEET
• WV-100-INFO — Information sheet
• CIVIL CASE COVER SHEET — CM-010
• CLETS-001 — Confidential CLETS Information
• WV-100 — Request for Workplace Violence Restraining Orders
• WV-109 — Notice of Court Hearing
• WV-110 — Temporary Restraining Order (ONLY if asking for immediate protection)
• WV-200-INFO — Firearms Information
• WV-200 — Proof of Firearms Turned In, Sold, or Stored
• WV-120 — Response to Request for Workplace Violence Restraining Order
• WV-250 — Proof of Service by Mail
    • WV-800 — Firearms Relinquishment Options Sheet

WV_Step2.text: Step 2: Go to Civil Ex Parte for judicial review (judge review happens BEFORE filing)

WV_ExParteRules.text:
San Mateo Civil Ex Parte rules:
• Hearings are Monday–Friday at 2:00 pm
• You must be in the courtroom by 2:00 pm (no later than 2:15 pm)
• If you arrive after 2:15 pm, the courtroom will not allow you to enter
• Check in with the Civil Department Clerk’s Office to confirm which courtroom Ex Parte will be in that day
• Your restraining order packet must be fully completed before 2:00 pm
    • The clerk does NOT file the papers first — the judge reviews them, then the papers must be filed

WV_JudgeDecision.text:
The judge may:
• Grant a temporary restraining order and set a hearing date, or
    • Deny the request

WV_FileAfter.text: Step 3: File the papers after the judge reviews/signs (as directed by the clerk/judge)

WV_Service.text:
Service rules:
• Someone over 18 (not you) must serve the papers
• The San Mateo County Sheriff will attempt service of process for restraining orders free of charge
    • Sheriff’s Office: 300 Bradford Street, 1st Floor, Redwood City, CA

WV_Step5.text: Step 5: Go to court on the hearing date listed on WV-109

WV_AfterHearing.text:
If the judge grants the order after the hearing, it can include:
• No contact
• Stay-away from employees and the workplace
• No harassment, stalking, or threats
    • Firearm, ammunition, and body armor restrictions

WV_Read.text: If an employer filed court papers asking for a Workplace Violence Restraining Order against you, carefully read all the papers you were served.

WV_Respond.text: Respond to a Workplace Violence Restraining Order (If You Were Served)

WV_Check109.text:
Check WV-109 (Notice of Court Hearing).
    This form lists your court date, time, and location.

WV_CourtNeeded.text:
If you do not agree with the restraining order, you must go to court.
    At the hearing, a judge decides whether to issue a Workplace Violence Restraining Order against you.

WV_Check110.text: Did the judge sign WV-110 (Temporary Restraining Order)?

WV_ObeyTRO.text:
You must follow every order in WV-110 immediately.
    If you do not, you could be arrested and charged with a crime.

WV_ResponseOpt.text: Would you like to respond in writing before court? This is optional.

WV120.text:
Fill out WV-120 — Response to Request for Workplace Violence Restraining Order.
    Attach any evidence you want the judge to review.

WV_PrepCourt.text:
Prepare for court:
Bring copies of your response, any evidence, and notes of what you want to say.
    Arrive early.

WV_ServeResp.text:
Have someone 18+ (not you) serve your response as required.
    File proof of service with the court before the hearing.

WV_GoCourt.text: Go to court on the date listed in WV-109.

TriageRO.text: Unsure what restraining order you need?

Start.text: What is your relationship to the person you want protection from?

CloseRel.text: Are they someone you are/were dating, married to, have a child with, or a close family member (parent, sibling, grandparent, in-law)?

DVROEntry.text: You may qualify for a Domestic Violence Restraining Order

ElderAge.text: Are you 65 or older, or between 18–64 with a disability?

SpecialCheck.text: Which situation best matches what you need help with?

CROInfo.text: Is the harm done by someone you are NOT closely related to, for example, a neighbor, roommate, or stranger?

CRONO.text: If you are looking for another type of restraining order not listed here, please see the Self-Help Center staff or speak with an attorney.

edges.when: No, I would like someone else to serve it for me
No, I would like someone else to serve it for me
I’m worried someone may hurt themselves or others with a gun
I’m an employer trying to protect an employee at the workplace
